Hi, folks!
I've gotten a couple of people asking when book four, Starcaster, is coming out from DIC author Kat Parrish. It was due in late 2013. I thought I'd answer you all at once.
Kat Parrish has been ill. I hadn't heard from her In a while, so I took this opportunity to contact her. Good news is, she's much better. Better news is, Starcaster is now due in early summer 2014.
Everyone should have gotten all their rewards by now--of the ones made. :) Still outstanding are , the short story and the audiobook, depending on your pledge level. I have finally landed studio time! I may be recording it myself or arranging with a noted local actor; we haven't figured it out yet, but I'm not having any luck finding a narrator at ACX. Either way, I'll be recording the books in my other series myself. It's gonna take tiiiime cuz those books is loooooong... If I end up doing myself, it'll go faster. I'll keep you apprised.

Hey, folks!
We're packing books today! If you're local to me, I'll be getting together with you personally--most of you I see on a semi-regular basis. Domestic folks, your packages are going out tomorrow and Tuesday; internationals, yours are going out Friday because of all the stupid ugly paperwork.
Coffee package people, I still need to get your goodies and the coffee is being roasted. I'm hoping Friday along with the internationals.

A mysterious box wrapped in frog leather and accompanied by an opinionated owl just arrived. Inside was a Jerian bansu, a turquoise kikoi, a pound of finely ground, highly aromatic coffee, and a whole bunch of books...

Yes, the paperbacks have arrived! If you're local to me, contact me and we'll get together for a book delivery. Otherwise, we'll be doing our best to get these out ASAP. This week is being eaten by a grue, and this weekend we'll be at Rose City Comic Con (as attendees, not panelists), but we'll do our best to crank these out. The coffee packages will take a little longer, as the coffee has to be roasted, ground, etc. And the international packages will take a little longer than that, because, hey, international.

Audiobook news: there isn't any. I'm having trouble attracting a narrator. I may have to do it myself. I've actually found affordable studio space, so this may be happening sooner than later. Now that I've recovered from my heart surgery in July, I'm ready to face that challenge. Would that be okay with you guys? I'd be recording it alongside recording books one and two of the History series. If it helps, I'm a former voice talent. :)

Sequel news: the sequel, "Songbird," is mapped out and ready to go as my NaNoWriMo project. The Drifting Isle books are all intended to be short--around 60k--and so doing this as a NaNo is totally feasible. If so, it may hit the stores in early 2014.

In other news: You're going to want to do that. I'm going to be announcing some pretty awesome stuff in the next few weeks, and you're going to want to know about it.

Almost done! Yay!

MeiLin

They should be here midmonth, which means I'm on schedule for end of month fulfillment. Huzzay!
I'll be working on my second Drifting Isle book, Songbird, during NaNoWriMo and will Kickstart it probably some time in early 2014. Songbird will feature Johanna Diederich and Simon Ritter, who are mentioned several times in The Machine God. They were originally the creations of Coral Moore, who had to drop out of the Drifting Isle project, and she's graciously allowed me to have my way with them. mwahahaha etc. Adewole may make an appearance, in fact, I expect it--which means so will Ofira. :)

I gave up on the relatively minor artistic detail I could not resolve with CreateSpace, and I'll be ordering paperbacks within the next week. I hope to have them in your hands end of September for domestic. International I hope to have shipped by then, but they take more time to get where they're going, obviously. :) Thanks for your patience, this has been a really weird, difficult year for us.

updates.update_userinfo: Why the paperbacks are late: CreateSpace
updates.update_content:
I have been trying to get The Machine God printed since April. I have a book signing Friday, and I've got to get books for you guys. I guess I won't be signing (or selling) TMG Friday, because CreateSpace can't manage to print a simple graphic.

The wordmark--the book's title as it appears on the first page of the book--is a 400 dpi graphic. It's the same kind of graphic I've had in all three of my last CS books, nothing unusual about it. They can't seem to print it without pixelating it or feathering the edges, and they can't coherently tell me why. I've gotten conflicting reasons, conflicting reports as to which graphics--it's been one giant cluster-badword the whole three months I've been trying to resolve things. I have a book designer. We are not amateurs.

I gave up and submitted the file with a font title page in place of the graphic, but it looks amateurish and it's not what I want. I can't get the books in time for the signing anyway, even if I pay ten times normal shipping for overnight (and eat my profit margin completely). The last straw was when I tried to give feedback and got a canned response reminding me to make sure my graphics were at least 300 dpi.

Every single time I've done a book with CS, it's something. Can't find my ISBN, messed up my cover, always something. Their front end people are great, but their back end can't find its back end with both hands. This time I encountered such incompetence that I'm moving my books to LSI. I'm just fed up. I'm sorry this is taking so long, guys.

Speaking of that reading: it's at here in Portland, Friday the 5th at 5 pm. I'm sharing the reading with the awesome Sara Mueller! If you like steampunk, you can't afford to miss this con!

I really really want the proper wordmark in this paperback. It doesn't look right without it. Tim and I have made more than a few books via CreateSpace, and we've never had problems like this. I'm furious, but we're still plugging away. I just wanted you to know I haven't forgotten you.
I'm still waiting on audiobook auditions, too.
That's where we stand, my dears. The book is doing well--not burning up the charts, but well for early days--and I have you to thanks.

Hi, folks:
I'm working with Tim Sevenhuysen, our typographer, to get this puppy put to bed. As per usual, CreateSpace has opened up a fresh hell this time around. Every time! Every time I make a book with them, it's something else! Oy!
Anyway, we're trying one last time before we give up on including the graphic wordmarks--the pretty, artistic book title rather than a plain text one. So far, CreateSpace is insisting on printing them in a gray screen tone instead of a solid black. Cross your fingers.

The good news: in print, the book looks terrific! The bad news: except for the wordmark--the graphic title on the first page. I haven't figured out what the problem is and neither has CreateSpace. I just wanted you to know I haven't forgotten all about this. I could drop back to a text version instead of the graphic, but the entire reason I put out paperbacks is for them to be good-looking. The font is eh, okay, but Elsa's embellishments make it something else entirely. I'm going to go bitch at CreateSpace some more, excuse me... ;)

By now a lot of you have downloaded and read the book. I hope you liked it! Either way, it's rate/review time.
If you're a Goodreads member, please add the book to your shelf. If you can add an honest star rating (so far there are two 5s and a 2), that'd be wonderful. If you could then give it a brief written review, that'd be even MORE wonderful, but do what you can. Here's the book on Goodreads.

Update #1: Day 1. What a start!
Welcome To The 8-Bit World!
Piko Piko Detroit is a Netlabel and a collective of artists who love and embrace the 8-bit cultures: video games, chiptunes, pixel art, glitches, etc. We founded ourselves in late 2011 when we realized that there wasn't a lively community in the Midwest area for live shows and social community.
In one year, we have grown to a collective of over 30 local musicians and artists. And now we are reaching out to the Midwest region to expand our collective to explore new creative ideas for the future.
Our goal is to help the internet based community inspire and make a difference to real people and societies. Not just online.
Why IRL? Why Detroit?
We heard that excuse many times--bad timing, bad economy, bad politics, bad tastes, and bad people in general. But, the truth is, most of us are dismissing our skillful passions as 'just hobbies' or conveniently 'things to do online'. And we see this as a major issue especially in the Detroit, Michigan where society is begging for change.
We see it differently.
As much as we love and support the DIY and Internet culture, we still believe that some things have to be done In Real Life to develop ideas and move emotions, here, where our life matters most!
Flashback 2012
Our first year has been super memorable. We've performed at home parties, cafes, bars, anime-cons, and even science festivals. Our audience ranged widely from adorable 5 year old girls dancing to our piko-sounds to curious elders asking us rather complex questions even we couldn't answer. Now we have 10 year old performer that jams on his LSDJ. This gives us true smiles that will live long in our hearts, and we don't want to stop.
Here's a list of this year's highlights:
12 Consecutive Monthly Open-Mic at Lab Cafe - Ann Arbor, MI
Chip Charged! Chiptune Show - Ann Arbor, MI
8-Ball Saloon at Blind Pig - Ann Arbor, MI
University of Michigan - Ann Arbor, MI
1-Day Mini GameStop Tour - Ann Arbor, Taylor, Ypsilanti, MI
Relay For Life of Chesterfield 2011 - Chesterfield, MI
Penguicon 2012 - Dearborn, MI
Invitation to Wreck-It Ralph Premiere - Birmingham, MI
Detroit Luvs Robots - Detroit, MI
Maker Faire Detroit 2012 (w/Editor's Award!) - Detroit, MI
Youmacon 2012 - Detroit, MI
Piko Invades Canada - Windsor, CA
And of course dozens of other shows that our local performers have been invited to throughout Michigan (Pontiac, Bay City, etc.), and neighboring states (Ohio, Virginia, Philadelphia, etc.).
Why Kickstarter?
We believe our story can inspire and impact the world around us.
Our community is driven by our passion, and our management members dedicate hours of their time to maintain a creative atmosphere and help support/promote our participating artists.
We do our best to keep our events free and open to the public. We select venues carefully to maintain a low budget while reaching out to as many people as we can. With the amazing support of our friends and families, it has been a very successful year! With the right mindset and a passion to evolve, even a hobby can change your life into something wonderful.
Today, we wanted to share these experiences with you.
So... We Need Your Help!
With a successful funding, the PPD Netlabel will become the initiator and foundation of creative projects in the Midwest region. We will help provide travel and hospitality for our guest performers at events, and we'll expand our tours to a variety of conventions and festivals around the nation, where we will continue to spread our stories.
To make these dreams come true, we are currently building a team behind the Netlabel to help organize and expand our productions to larger scale projects and shows. Depending on your contribution, 2013 will become a life changing moment for every one involved in the Piko Piko Detroit community.
The Amazing Rewards♥
We will thank every backer of $8 or more with an 8-bit profile picture!
Get a Kickstarter Edition PPD Shirt designed by Ohhinaifu!
PPD Netlabel Releases (PPD-001 to 006)
All 2012 PPD Netlabel Releases signed by the artists + 1 brand new compilation album in physical packages! Compilation artists TBA. Our releases are free to download at www.pikopikodetroit.net
Midwest Collective 2013
We have upgraded our compilation to 2-discs with over 45 artists for music and design! Cover and CD designs are currently being developed by our amazing local talent!
2:22 Audio Preview
Artists Highlights: Alienation Innovation (MI), b4by f4c3 (MI), BeatScribe (IL), Clyde Machine (MI), Danger! Captain, Danger! (IA), Saskrotch (IL), SDDN MVMNTS (MI).
PPD Fan Kit! ($16 or More)
Some Piko swag to make your daily life sweeter!
PPD Piko Show For You! ($96 or $160 or More)
We'll perform anywhere 50 to 200 miles from Detroit, MI just for you! Your package will include a mini PA system with 3 or more artists from our collective, and your funding will help pay for their food and gas. Artists and performance schedule may vary.
Thank You!
We're super excited about this kickstarter project and hope to share the piko love with the whole world. Please share if you like us!
- Piko Piko Detroit
Trivia: "Piko-Piko" is a Japanese term for "Bleep-Bleep" and we use it as a term for chiptune and 8-bit inspired material because it sounds cute and fun. Our art is not limited to any specific square wave or number of pixels. And we are open to the wide range of possibilities the culture provides. We love Piko Piko!

campaign.story:
What Is Dynagirl About?
This story chronicles the adventures of a superhero single mom. After gaining powers at a very early age, Kerri Masters ran into one serious life event after another. She was enslaved by a maniacal villain, forced to help some of the world most heinous villains kill her live-in boyfriend rather than watch him destroy the world, and found herself alone and carrying a child who could well develop more power than both of his parents combined. Raising kids is already a herculean challenge. Raising a kid with enough power to crack planets is a whole new ballgame! After five years of retirement, Dynagirl has the urge and the opportunity to return to hero work, but should she?
Overall Theme: At the heart of things Dynagirl is about how very real the whole hero game can come to be, and how our choices in life stay with us forever. Sure, she might stop a plane from crashing into the ocean, or save an old lady from crossing the street into oncoming traffic, but she’s still got every day life, and her son, to deal with when she goes home at night. With this story we tackle things most comics never go anywhere near, and we do it because it's compelling and makes for a great comic.
Our characters are regular normal people faced with incredible situations. Dynagirl is without a doubt a character driven story centering mainly on our main character, but also tossing several other very interesting and flawed individuals into the mix as her supporting cast.
Why It’s Different: Dynagirl is so much more real. The art is stylized to portray people as they would actually look rather than the Barbie and Ken reality seen in most comics these days. People have weight, they have flaws, they look like real people look! The story is also a deep, and often fun take on the superhero genre. It's serious and smart without portraying the world around us as too dark or sinister. There will be villains, and many of them very terrifying, but in Dynagirl, there’s always hope, and with hope you can do anything.  
Praise for our previous work:
John Barringer for acomicbookblog.com: “This story is thicker than molasses and issue #2 just increases the potential of some great story telling. Take a break from the mainstream and pick up this story.”
pigs-of-the-industry.blogspot.com: “One of the best things about this comic is the way it handles its large cast of characters. It’s easy to believe these heroes and villains have been fighting it out for a while now. You should check out this title and the other works from Red Handed Studios, it's worth it.”
interestingfodder.typepad.com: “The imagery on this comic is just great.” 
Bill Gladman for Comicrelated.com: “anything but just "another super-hero story" Believable characters in a believable situation...makes you forget this is a super-hero story.” 
Sean Kleefeld kleefeldoncomics.blogspot.com: (About Dynagirl) “Here's a comic that's purportedly one in a long-line of superhero comics. A genre in which women (at least the superheroines) are portrayed in precisely one way with variations being almost exclusively limited to hair color and/or style. But what I'm presented with is something which, for me, is not only unexpected but more appealing.”
Harold Edge nominated for Project Fanboy Best Independent Artist award in 2009 for his work on Fallen Justice. 
Cary Kelley (Red Handed Studios)-Best Indie Publisher 2010 for Fallen Justice and Dynagirl.
The Creative Team: 
Creators- Cary Kelley and Harold Edge 
Writer - Cary Kelley 
Artist - Harold Edge (Sixgun Samurai, Fallen Justice, The Trouble With Love) 
Colors – Lisa Moore, Paul John Little, Sarah Perryman, Ernest Jocson 
Letters – Cary Kelley 
Why Kickstarter and What's the Plan: Dynagirl has always been intended to be an ongoing series, and we haven’t changed that vision. What has changed has to do with life and economic situations, which now force us to reach out for alternative means of funding the work we love to produce. What we want to do now is take the story we have already completed and get it out there to as many people as possible in printed form, as well as fund the completion of the next chapter in her story. Our first focus will be to take the first six issues of Dynagirl and put them into one complete volume, including a ton of sketchbook and behind the scenes stuff. We will use collected funds for printing costs, promotional purposes for getting the word out, and to produce and ship all backer rewards. Anything beyond our funding goal will go directly to producing the next Dynagirl book.   
The music for our video, (used with permission!) comes from pretty much the coolest band in the whole  world! They're called Tartanic, and you should seriously check them out!

This time around, we've got the entire bulk of the comic already completed, we just need the means to put it into print and get it out there.

Check it out.
It may not seem like someone making an album entirely on a computer needs money to finish a project, but there's more to it than just some clicks and keystrokes.
Making this project is something I plan to invest hundreds of hours in, and it's going to be the most incredible piece of work I can possibly make it. However, there's only so much I can do on my own.
First, I have to record a lot of different sounds in a studio that I'll have to pay for. This includes vocal tracks from guests, and environment sound capture. This isn't cheap, especially for the kind of quality I'm looking for.
Secondly, I have to like, promote the crap out of this thing. In order for this project to really be recognized, it needs some, well, recognition. People need to see this thing everywhere they look.
Lastly, in order to make sure this project is a music industry success, it has to meet music industry standards. Meaning it has to be listened to and tweaked by a Master of Sound, which is very costly depending on exactly what they do with it.
Most importantly, this is a free album. Anyone anywhere can download this and listen to it at any point upon its' release, but physical copies will be the cost of shipping. That being said, I'll be receiving but a few dollars, if anything, from YouTube views, so I really need your support here.
There are a lot of really sweet deals you can get if you choose to be a part of this thing, and you don't understand how badly i want you to go on this journey with me. If there's any reason I do this, it's for you, my friends and family, and the joy of sharing the music I create.
Please consider helping me make this project the best it can be. I can't wait to share it with you!

Risks and challenges
We have already invested £80,000 of our own money and resources into the development of the film to date through our company Movie Mogul Ltd. There’s no escaping the fact that filmmaking is an expensive business! As soon as we hit the Kickstarter £100,000 target, we will be in a position to approach film financiers for the remaining budget (currently estimated at £3m).

It is fair to point out that it is possible that we may become delayed in this process, for a multitude of unforeseen circumstances beyond our control and despite our best endeavours. You should take assurance from the fact that we know how to make a film happen as we did with PANIC BUTTON. The key to success is always momentum, driving the vision forward and finding solutions to all issues that are thrown our way. Without this resilience and resourcefulness, we would never have come so far already.
 
The Kickstarter community should know that whatever we plan, and whatever obstacles are thrown in our path, we are focussed on our goals and passionate in honouring our commitment to our pledges to you. The more support we have – the stronger and more determined we become to make this happen, it really is that simple.
 
We believe in clear and worthwhile communications, so whilst we might not be bugging you every five minutes with updates, you will always be the first to know when we have some exciting news, and if we have to make any changes of direction, you will be kept fully informed also.
 
We cannot make a firm guarantee to you that after a successful £100k raise, we will 100% be able to secure the full estimated £3m budget. What we can guarantee however, is that as soon as we raise significant funds to make the film, we will do exactly that, cutting our cloth accordingly, without compromising the vision for the film in any way. Necessity is the mother of all invention, not money. As a team we create, we find solutions and we deliver on our promises. Our business depends on it!
 
Embarking upon this journey with us will be a unique, exciting and rewarding experience on many levels, that much we do guarantee. Thank you for reading.

updates.update_content:
So... 4 days to go in the brand new WE ARE MONSTERS campaign. (See the campaign here)
We hit our first target. In record time. 
Then we smashed our stretch target...
...before doing something even more exciting.

updates.update_userinfo: WE ARE MONSTERS - New Stretch Goal!
updates.update_content:
This is a message for all of the backers of the original WE ARE MONSTERS campaign. 
So, so many of you have rejoined us and for that we are truly grateful. 
For those of you that haven't, we'd really love it if you did. We're working our socks off to make the best movie we can and are really going to town on some awesome rewards, too. 
We have just over one week to go and we want to make it something special!

updates.update_userinfo: WE ARE MONSTERS RE-BOOT - ONE WEEK IN!
updates.update_content:
So far, so good. 
During the first hour of the re-launched WE ARE MONSTERS campaign we have over 20 backers, £1,500 pledged meaning we are already over 30% towards our goal. 
This is not a reason to sit back though. The rewards are as great as ever so please do get involved and help us continue marching towards our goal at this speed. The quicker we go, the more we will get noticed on the MOST POPULAR page through Kickstarter meaning we get more traffic to our page!
